job_title: Adjunct Faculty in San Dimas, CA
pros: As in any university, some of the students are engaged, committed, and a joy to work with.
cons: The disregard for faculty is very telling. Pay is quite low ($28.25/hour for an advanced degree, $32/hour for a terminal degree). Faculty have not been given a raise or cost of living adjustment in over a decade. We work on an eight-week contract, with no benefits, and no input on course design. Faculty input is requested each session, but never implemented. We are forced to sign a non-litigation agreement, further eroding faculty rights in an already-powerless position. If enrollment is low, contracts are renewed and no notice is given. All of these issues indicate a complete lack of respect for the expertise, lives, and working conditions of the people who are actually doing the work of teaching.

job_title: Benefits Administrator in San Dimas, CA
pros: The mid-level, entry level peers were the best people to work with. The peer-to-peer support (spiritually and professionally) was amazing. Unfortunately, there was more peers having to make other peers feel better for all the drama of working here under certain leadership.
cons:
There are better alternatives to attend school or work at then here. APU is definitely top notch for a Christian University. LAPU is not. Don’t believe me. They changed their billboards from “Online, Affordable, Christian” to “Online, Affordable, non-profit”. Not the best endorsement for a Christian workplace. 
Human Resources was notorious for sharing personal and medical information with other coworkers. Example. One former employee had a mental breakdown after being bullied. She went on medical leave and then into litigation: so H R decided to have IT search her computer and found her journal which was shared with everyone. 
I had my medical info shared with another coworker who wasn’t on my contact list. You would think H R knew the policy on an employee personal information that can and cannot be shared with anyone. Apparently not. That is pretty embarrassing for a director to not know basic employee privacy.
A former employee mentioned how the Registrar and Support Central created bogus programs to push the non degree seeking students into a program that would show completion- which in turns pads the numbers to the Department of Education and the National Student Clearinghouse. This unfortunately caused many Active duty Military students to lose their tuition assistance. The new Support Central Dir responded “have them use their GI Bill” totally oblivious to the fact that it was too late AND it was a waste of GI Bill for Active Duty Soldiers. One soldier used her GI bill and was forced to pay back the Tuition Assistance because the new program wasn’t approved by the Army.
Padding the numbers worked! They made the top Military Friendly list after all of that.
Thankfully I am still connected with the Military Connected community that I get asked if LAPU is a good place to work, or school to attend, and I can steer them away from this soup sandwich. With all this free time on my hands I can make sure my community doesn’t get sucked into this place.

pros: Excellent PTO- 30 days, monthly lunches, and some great benefits (at least when I was there). This school showed appreciation for its employees through many little things as well: free coffee, snacks, and workshops. Also, most of the people working there were amazing and I will always treasure these interactions.  The sense of community I experienced outside a select group was inspiring.
cons:
I experienced extended targeting in various forms from a select group for nearly the entire time I was employed (over 2 years) aimed at my job performance, character & strangely, my friendships. It was a very scary and heartbreaking experience involving multiple forms of betrayal from people I cared about, helped, and valued spanning over my entire time working for this school. I stayed because I needed to pay for my theological education and turned out some good work despite everything.

In my opinion, the values the school espoused were consistently not followed.
